page.title: 05RELIGION
page.content: There are only two places of worship, both Church of England churches. The older of the two, and the more interesting is Curcham, which is set on the top of a small hill and has an unusual helm spire, one of only two in the country. It was built by William de Rue, Lord of the Manor, as a reparation to Gloucester Abbey because his men had molested the monks. At the time when Gilbert Scott was redesigning churches, Churcham was spared by the Vicar who merely restored the building. All the timbers are joined with wooden pegs; there is said not to be a single nail used in its construction. Minsterworth did not escape the zeal of the Victorians. It is nevertheless a pleasant church with a square tower. An interesting feature inside is a carved net of fish on one of the pillars.
